JavaScript featues

Every feature on this page requires JavaScript and jQuery to use. This allows you to add some extra features that would not be possible otherwise.

Install JavaScript and jQuery

To use the optional JavaScript features, you must first install jQuery. Then, make sure all of your HTML files refer to the JavaScript folder, and make sure they run the cs_framework_js.document_ready() function. Here’s a sample header file that you would use to include the JavaScript.

					
<head>
  <!-- Add metatags -->

  <!-- Add jQuery -->
  <script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.3.1.min.js"></script>
	<!-- Include CSimple's JavaScript library -->
  <script src="js/cs-framework.js"></script>
	<!-- Include stylesheets here -->

  <!-- Add this JavaScript to turn on CSimple's JS features-->
	<script>
	  $(document).ready(function() {
	    cs_framework_js.document_ready();
	  });
	</script>
</head>

Click to reveal

Clickable elements can hide or reveal their immediate sibling. Just add the click-to-reveal class and the element can be hidden.

Here’s an example that hides and reveals a block of text when you click the button:


Click to reveal
						
<div class="row">
  <button class="click-to-reveal col3">Click me!</button>
  <div class="col3">Is this div hidden?</div>
</div>

Is this div hidden?

Slideshow

You can present a series of images that the user can scroll throw using the previous and next arrows.

To build this in HTML, you will need:

  • A container with the slideshow-container class.

  • Several divs with the slide and fade classes.

  • Each div has an image to display and a div with the slide-caption class.

  • Two anchor tags, with the previous-slide and next-slide classes.

The fade class is an animation, so feel free to ignore or replace it with your own. If the slideshow-container element also has the automatic class, the slideshow will advance to the next picture every 2 seconds until the user clicks on a button.

You can change the color of the slideshow buttons by changing this variable:

						
//The color of the previous and next slideshow buttons.
$slideshow-button-col: white;

Here is an example of the slideshow in action (replace &\ with &):


Slideshow HTML
						
<div class="slideshow-container automatic">
  <div class="slide fade">
    <img src="images/Vegetable_Samosa400x300.jpg"
		 alt="Vegetable Samosas">
    <div class="slide-caption">Vegetable Samosas</div>
  </div>
  <div class="slide fade">
    <img src="images/pasta-food-small.jpg"
		 alt="Vegan Alfredo with Penne and Broccoli">
    <div class="slide-caption">Vegan Alfredo</div>
  </div>
  <div class="slide fade">
    <img src="images/cake-table-small.jpg"
		 alt="Carrot Cake">
    <div class="slide-caption">Carrot Cake</div>
  </div>
  <a class="previous-slide">&\#10094;</a>
  <a class="next-slide">&\#10095;</a>
</div>
Vegetable Samosas
Vegan Alfredo
Carrot Cake

Smooth scrolling

Add the smoothscroll class and the href attribute with a hash. When the user clicks on this element, the browser will smoothly scroll to the element with that id. Here is an example code block you can use.


Smoothscroll
						
<a href="#top" class="smoothscroll">
Scroll to the top of the page</a>
Scroll to the top of the page
